newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Ugandan president to visit S.Africa from Tuesday.
newsitem.headline: Ugandan president to visit S.Africa from Tuesday.

text.p: Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni will sign a double taxation agreement with South Africa during a three-day state visit starting on Tuesday, South Africa's Foreign Affairs Department said on Friday.
Museveni, accompanied by Foreign Minister Eriya Kategaya, will meet President Nelson Mandela, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki and former president F.W. de Klerk.

The department said in a statement that economic ties with Uganda had recently strengthened, adding: "A number of South African companies are already active in Uganda, and this visit is expected to add further impetus to this trend."
Museveni, who seized power in 1986 after a five-year bush war, is regarded as an ally of Laurent Kabila, the rebel leader who ousted Zairean president Mobutu Sese Seko.

Western intelligence sources have said Ugandan and Rwandan forces fought alongside Kabila's rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo in the rebellion that began in the east last October.

Asked to comment on the reports earlier this week, Museveni told reporters in Kampala: "When people are fighting a war like the one in Zaire they have secrets, and since I am not one who gives information on secrets I won't tell you."
Mandela brokered the first face-to-face talks between Kabila and Mobutu as part of an international bid to ensure stability in Kinshasa.
